member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.BinaryPredicate`1
member.summary: The BinaryPredicate delegate type encapsulates a method that takes two items of the same type, and returns a boolean value representating some relationship between them. For example, checking whether two items are equal or equivalent is one kind of binary predicate.
member.returns: Whether item1 and item2 satisfy the relationship that the BinaryPredicate defines.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms
member.summary: Algorithms contains a number of static methods that implement algorithms that work on collections. Most of the methods deal with the standard generic collection interfaces such as IEnumerable<T>, ICollection<T> and IList<T>.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.Range``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a view onto a sub-range of a list. Items from are not copied; the returned IList<T> is simply a different view onto the same underlying items. Changes to are reflected in the view, and vice versa. Insertions and deletions in the view change the size of the view, but insertions and deletions in the underlying list do not.
member.remarks: This method can be used to apply an algorithm to a portion of a list. For example: Algorithms.ReverseInPlace(Algorithms.Range(list, 3, 6)) will reverse the 6 items beginning at index 3.
member.typeparam: The type of the items in the list.
member.param: The starting index of the view.
The number of items in the view.
member.returns: A list that is a view onto the given sub-list.
member.exception: is null.
or is negative.
+ is greater than the size of .

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.Range``1(``0[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a view onto a sub-range of an array. Items from are not copied; the returned IList<T> is simply a different view onto the same underlying items. Changes to are reflected in the view, and vice versa. Insertions and deletions in the view change the size of the view. After an insertion, the last item in "falls off the end". After a deletion, the last item in array becomes the default value (0 or null).
member.remarks: This method can be used to apply an algorithm to a portion of a array. For example: Algorithms.ReverseInPlace(Algorithms.Range(array, 3, 6)) will reverse the 6 items beginning at index 3.
member.param: The starting index of the view.
The number of items in the view.
member.returns: A list that is a view onto the given sub-array.
member.exception: is null.
or is negative.
+ is greater than the size of .

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.ReadOnly``1(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{``0})
member.summary: Returns a read-only view onto a collection. The returned ICollection<T> interface only allows operations that do not change the collection: GetEnumerator, Contains, CopyTo, Count. The ReadOnly property returns false, indicating that the collection is read-only. All other methods on the interface throw a NotSupportedException.
member.remarks: The data in the underlying collection is not copied. If the underlying collection is changed, then the read-only view also changes accordingly.
member.typeparam: The type of items in the collection.
member.returns: A read-only view onto . If is null, then null is returned.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.ReadOnly``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0})
member.summary: Returns a read-only view onto a list. The returned IList<T> interface only allows operations that do not change the list: GetEnumerator, Contains, CopyTo, Count, IndexOf, and the get accessor of the indexer. The IsReadOnly property returns true, indicating that the list is read-only. All other methods on the interface throw a NotSupportedException.
member.remarks: The data in the underlying list is not copied. If the underlying list is changed, then the read-only view also changes accordingly.
member.typeparam: The type of items in the list.
member.returns: A read-only view onto . Returns null if is null. If is already read-only, returns .

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.ReadOnly``2(System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{``0,``1})
member.summary: Returns a read-only view onto a dictionary. The returned IDictionary<TKey,TValue> interface only allows operations that do not change the dictionary. The IsReadOnly property returns true, indicating that the dictionary is read-only. All other methods on the interface throw a NotSupportedException.
member.remarks: The data in the underlying dictionary is not copied. If the underlying dictionary is changed, then the read-only view also changes accordingly.
member.returns: A read-only view onto . Returns null if is null. If is already read-only, returns .

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.TypedAs``1(System.Collections.IEnumerable)
member.summary: Given a non-generic IEnumerable interface, wrap a generic IEnumerable<T> interface around it. The generic interface will enumerate the same objects as the underlying non-generic collection, but can be used in places that require a generic interface. The underlying non-generic collection must contain only items that are of type or a type derived from it. This method is useful when interfacing older, non-generic collections to newer code that uses generic interfaces.
member.remarks: Some collections implement both generic and non-generic interfaces. For efficiency, this method will first attempt to cast to IEnumerable<T>. If that succeeds, it is returned; otherwise, a wrapper object is created.
member.typeparam: The item type of the wrapper collection.
member.param: An untyped collection. This collection should only contain items of type or a type derived from it.
member.returns: A generic IEnumerable<T> wrapper around . If is null, then null is returned.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.TypedAs``1(System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Given a non-generic ICollection interface, wrap a generic ICollection<T> interface around it. The generic interface will enumerate the same objects as the underlying non-generic collection, but can be used in places that require a generic interface. The underlying non-generic collection must contain only items that are of type or a type derived from it. This method is useful when interfacing older, non-generic collections to newer code that uses generic interfaces.

remarks.para: Some collections implement both generic and non-generic interfaces. For efficiency, this method will first attempt to cast to ICollection<T>. If that succeeds, it is returned; otherwise, a wrapper object is created.

Unlike the generic interface, the non-generic ICollection interfaces does not contain methods for adding or removing items from the collection. For this reason, the returned ICollection<T> will be read-only.

member.typeparam: The item type of the wrapper collection.
member.param: An untyped collection. This collection should only contain items of type or a type derived from it.
member.returns: A generic ICollection<T> wrapper around . If is null, then null is returned.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.TypedAs``1(System.Collections.IList)
member.summary: Given a non-generic IList interface, wrap a generic IList<T> interface around it. The generic interface will enumerate the same objects as the underlying non-generic list, but can be used in places that require a generic interface. The underlying non-generic list must contain only items that are of type or a type derived from it. This method is useful when interfacing older, non-generic lists to newer code that uses generic interfaces.
member.remarks: Some collections implement both generic and non-generic interfaces. For efficiency, this method will first attempt to cast to IList<T>. If that succeeds, it is returned; otherwise, a wrapper object is created.
member.typeparam: The item type of the wrapper list.
member.param: An untyped list. This list should only contain items of type or a type derived from it.
member.returns: A generic IList<T> wrapper around . If is null, then null is returned.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.Untyped``1(System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{``0})
member.summary: Given a generic ICollection<T> interface, wrap a non-generic (untyped) ICollection interface around it. The non-generic interface will contain the same objects as the underlying generic collection, but can be used in places that require a non-generic interface. This method is useful when interfacing generic interfaces with older code that uses non-generic interfaces.
member.remarks: Many generic collections already implement the non-generic interfaces directly. This method will first attempt to simply cast to ICollection. If that succeeds, it is returned; if it fails, then a wrapper object is created.
member.typeparam: The item type of the underlying collection.
member.returns: A non-generic ICollection wrapper around . If is null, then null is returned.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.Untyped``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0})
member.summary: Given a generic IList<T> interface, wrap a non-generic (untyped) IList interface around it. The non-generic interface will contain the same objects as the underlying generic list, but can be used in places that require a non-generic interface. This method is useful when interfacing generic interfaces with older code that uses non-generic interfaces.
member.remarks: Many generic collections already implement the non-generic interfaces directly. This method will first attempt to simply cast to IList. If that succeeds, it is returned; if it fails, then a wrapper object is created.
member.typeparam: The item type of the underlying list.
member.returns: A non-generic IList wrapper around . If is null, then null is returned.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.ReadWriteList``1(``0[])

summary.para: Creates a read-write IList<T> wrapper around an array. When an array is implicitely converted to an IList<T>, changes to the items in the array cannot be made through the interface. This method creates a read-write IList<T> wrapper on an array that can be used to make changes to the array.

Use this method when you need to pass an array to an algorithms that takes an IList<T> and that tries to modify items in the list. Algorithms in this class generally do not need this method, since they have been design to operate on arrays even when they are passed as an IList<T>.

member.remarks: Since arrays cannot be resized, inserting an item causes the last item in the array to be automatically removed. Removing an item causes the last item in the array to be replaced with a default value (0 or null). Clearing the list causes all the items to be replaced with a default value.
member.returns: An IList<T> wrapper onto .

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.RemoveDuplicates``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},DmFramework.Collections.BinaryPredicate{``0})
member.summary: Remove consecutive "equal" items from a collection, yielding another collection. In each run of consecutive equal items in the collection, all items after the first item in the run are removed. The passed BinaryPredicate is used to determine if two items are "equal".
member.remarks: Since an arbitrary BinaryPredicate is passed to this function, what is being removed need not be true equality.
member.param: The BinaryPredicate used to compare items for "equality". An item current is removed if predicate(first, current)==true, where first is the first item in the group of "duplicate" items.
member.returns: An new collection with the items from , in the same order, with consecutive "duplicates" removed.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.FindLastWhere``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Predicate{``0})
member.summary: Finds the last item in a collection that satisfies the condition defined by .

remarks.para: If the collection implements IList<T>, then the list is scanned in reverse until a matching item is found. Otherwise, the entire collection is iterated in the forward direction.

If the default value for T could be present in the collection, and would be matched by the predicate, then this method is inappropriate, because you cannot disguish whether the default value for T was actually present in the collection, or no items matched the predicate. In this case, use TryFindFirstWhere.

member.param: A delegate that defined the condition to check for.
member.returns: The last item in the collection that matches the condition, or the default value for T (0 or null) if no item that matches the condition is found.

member.returns: True if an item satisfying the condition was found. False if no such item exists in the collection.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.IsSubsetOf``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Determines if one collection is a subset of another, considered as sets. The first set is a subset of the second set if every item in the first set also occurs in the second set. If an item appears X times in the first set, it must appear at least X times in the second set.

remarks.para: The default sense of equality for T is used, as defined by T's implementation of IComparable<T>.Equals or object.Equals.
If both collections are Set, Bag, OrderedSet, or OrderedBag collections, it is more efficient to use the IsSubsetOf method on that class.

member.returns: True if is a subset of , considered as sets.
member.exception: or is null.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.SetIntersection``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Computes the set-theoretic intersection of two collections. The intersection of two sets is all items that appear in both of the sets. If an item appears X times in one set, and Y times in the other set, the intersection contains the item Minimum(X,Y) times. The source collections are not changed. A new collection is created with the intersection of the collections; the order of the items in this collection is undefined.

remarks.para: When equal items appear in both collections, the returned collection will include an arbitrary choice of one of the two equal items.
The default sense of equality for T is used, as defined by T's implementation of IComparable<T>.Equals or object.Equals.
If both collections are Set, Bag, OrderedSet, or OrderedBag collections, it is more efficient to use the Intersection or IntersectionWith methods on that class.

member.returns: The intersection of the two collections, considered as sets.
member.exception: or is null.

If an item appears X times in the first set, and Y times in the second set, the difference contains the item X - Y times (0 times if X < Y). The source collections are not changed. A new collection is created with the difference of the collections; the order of the items in this collection is undefined.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.ToString``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Gets a String representation of the elements in the collection. The String representation starts with "{", has a list of items separated by commas (","), and ends with "}". Each item in the collection is converted to a String by calling its ToString method (null is represented by "null"). Contained collections (except strings) are recursively converted to strings by this method.
member.param: A collection to get the String representation of.
member.returns: The String representation of the collection. If is null, then the String "null" is returned.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.ToString``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Boolean,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Gets a String representation of the elements in the collection. The String to used at the beginning and end, and to separate items, and supplied by parameters. Each item in the collection is converted to a String by calling its ToString method (null is represented by "null").
member.param: A collection to get the String representation of.
If true, contained collections (except strings) are converted to strings by a recursive call to this method, instead of by calling ToString.
The String to appear at the beginning of the output String.
The String to appear between each item in the String.
The String to appear at the end of the output String.
member.returns: The String representation of the collection. If is null, then the String "null" is returned.
member.exception: , , or is null.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.ToString``2(System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{``0,``1})
member.summary: Gets a String representation of the mappings in a dictionary. The String representation starts with "{", has a list of mappings separated by commas (", "), and ends with "}". Each mapping is represented by "key->value". Each key and value in the dictionary is converted to a String by calling its ToString method (null is represented by "null"). Contained collections (except strings) are recursively converted to strings by this method.
member.param: A dictionary to get the String representation of.
member.returns: The String representation of the collection, or "null" if is null.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.GeneratePermutations``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Generates all the possible permutations of the items in . If has N items, then N factorial permutations will be generated. This method does not compare the items to determine if any of them are equal. If some items are equal, the same permutation may be generated more than once. For example, if the collections contains the three items A, A, and B, then this method will generate the six permutations, AAB, AAB, ABA, ABA, BAA, BAA (not necessarily in that order). To take equal items into account, use the GenerateSortedPermutations method.
member.typeparam: The type of items to permute.
member.param: The collection of items to permute.
member.returns: An IEnumerable<T[]> that enumerations all the possible permutations of the items in . Each permutations is returned as an array. The items in the array should be copied if they need to be used after the next permutation is generated; each permutation may reuse the same array instance.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.GenerateSortedPermutations``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Generates all the possible permutations of the items in , in lexicographical order. Even if some items are equal, the same permutation will not be generated more than once. For example, if the collections contains the three items A, A, and B, then this method will generate only the three permutations, AAB, ABA, BAA.
member.typeparam: The type of items to permute.
member.param: The collection of items to permute.
member.returns: An IEnumerable<T[]> that enumerations all the possible permutations of the items in . Each permutations is returned as an array. The items in the array should be copied if they need to be used after the next permutation is generated; each permutation may reuse the same array instance.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.GenerateSortedPermutations``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IComparer{``0})
member.summary: Generates all the possible permutations of the items in , in lexicographical order. A supplied IComparer<T> instance is used to compare the items. Even if some items are equal, the same permutation will not be generated more than once. For example, if the collections contains the three items A, A, and B, then this method will generate only the three permutations, AAB, ABA, BAA.
member.typeparam: The type of items to permute.
member.param: The collection of items to permute.
The IComparer<T> used to compare the items.
member.returns: An IEnumerable<T[]> that enumerations all the possible permutations of the items in . Each permutations is returned as an array. The items in the array should be copied if they need to be used after the next permutation is generated; each permutation may reuse the same array instance.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.GenerateSortedPermutations``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Comparison{``0})
member.summary: Generates all the possible permutations of the items in , in lexicographical order. A supplied Comparison<T> delegate is used to compare the items. Even if some items are equal, the same permutation will not be generated more than once. For example, if the collections contains the three items A, A, and B, then this method will generate only the three permutations, AAB, ABA, BAA.
member.typeparam: The type of items to permute.
member.param: The collection of items to permute.
The Comparison<T> delegate used to compare the items.
member.returns: An IEnumerable<T[]> that enumerations all the possible permutations of the items in . Each permutations is returned as an array. The items in the array should be copied if they need to be used after the next permutation is generated; each permutation may reuse the same array instance.

member.summary: Sorts a list or array in place.

remarks.para: The Quicksort algorithms is used to sort the items. In virtually all cases, this takes time O(N log N), where N is the number of items in the list.
Values are compared by using the IComparable<T> interfaces implementation on the type T.
Although arrays cast to IList<T> are normally read-only, this method will work correctly and modify an array passed as .

member.param: The list or array to sort.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.LexicographicalCompare``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Performs a lexicographical comparison of two sequences of values. A lexicographical comparison compares corresponding pairs of elements from two sequences in order. If the first element of sequence1 is less than the first element of sequence2, then the comparison ends and the first sequence is lexicographically less than the second. If the first elements of each sequence are equal, then the comparison proceeds to the second element of each sequence. If one sequence is shorter than the other, but corresponding elements are all equal, then the shorter sequence is considered less than the longer one.
member.remarks: T must implement either IComparable<T> and this implementation is used to compare the items.
member.typeparam: Types of items to compare. This type must implement IComparable<T> to allow items to be compared.
member.returns: Less than zero if is lexicographically less than . Greater than zero if is lexicographically greater than . Zero if is equal to .
member.exception: T does not implement IComparable<T> or IComparable.

If one sequence is shorter than the other, but corresponding elements are all equal, then the shorter sequence is considered less than the longer one.
member.typeparam: Types of items to compare.
member.param: The IComparison<T> delegate to compare items. Only the Compare member function of this interface is called.
member.returns: Less than zero if is lexicographically less than . Greater than zero if is lexicographically greater than . Zero if is equal to .

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.GetCollectionEqualityComparer``1
member.summary: Gets an IEqualityComparer<IEnumerable<T>> implementation that can be used to compare collections of elements (of type T). Two collections of T's are equal if they have the same number of items, and corresponding items are equal, considered in order. This is the same notion of equality as in Algorithms.EqualCollections, but encapsulated in an IEqualityComparer<IEnumerable<T>> implementation.
member.returns: IEqualityComparer<IEnumerable<T>> implementation suitable for comparing collections of T for equality.

member.summary: Removes all the items in the collection that satisfy the condition defined by .
member.remarks: If the collection if an array or implements IList<T>, an efficient algorithm that compacts items is used. If not, then ICollection<T>.Remove is used to remove items from the collection. If the collection is an array or fixed-size list, the non-removed elements are placed, in order, at the beginning of the list, and the remaining list items are filled with a default value (0 or null).
member.param: The collection to check all the items in.
A delegate that defines the condition to check for.
member.returns: Returns a collection of the items that were removed. This collection contains the items in the same order that they orginally appeared in .

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.Partition``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},System.Predicate{``0})
member.summary: Partition a list or array based on a predicate. After partitioning, all items for which the predicate returned true precede all items for which the predicate returned false.
member.remarks: Although arrays cast to IList<T> are normally read-only, this method will work correctly and modify an array passed as .
member.param: The list or array to partition.
A delegate that defines the partitioning condition.
member.returns: The index of the first item in the second half of the partition; i.e., the first item for which returned false. If the predicate was true for all items in the list, list.Count is returned.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.StablePartition``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},System.Predicate{``0})
member.summary: Partition a list or array based on a predicate. After partitioning, all items for which the predicate returned true precede all items for which the predicate returned false. The partition is stable, which means that if items X and Y have the same result from the predicate, and X precedes Y in the original list, X will precede Y in the partitioned list.
member.remarks: Although arrays cast to IList<T> are normally read-only, this method will work correctly and modify an array passed as .
member.param: The list or array to partition.
A delegate that defines the partitioning condition.
member.returns: The index of the first item in the second half of the partition; i.e., the first item for which returned false. If the predicate was true for all items in the list, list.Count is returned.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.Algorithms.ListRange`1
member.summary: The class that is used to implement IList<T> to view a sub-range of a list. The object stores a wrapped list, and a start/count indicating a sub-range of the list. Insertion/deletions through the sub-range view cause the count to change also; insertions and deletions directly on the wrapped list do not.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.PowerListBase`1
member.summary: ListBase is an abstract class that can be used as a base class for a read-write collection that needs to implement the generic IList<T> and non-generic IList collections. The derived class needs to override the following methods: Count, Clear, Insert, RemoveAt, and the indexer. The implementation of all the other methods in IList<T> and IList are handled by ListBase.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.CollectionBase`1
member.summary: CollectionBase is a base class that can be used to more easily implement the generic ICollection<T> and non-generic ICollection interfaces.

remarks.para: To use CollectionBase as a base class, the derived class must override the Count, GetEnumerator, Add, Clear, and Remove methods.
ICollection<T>.Contains need not be implemented by the derived class, but it should be strongly considered, because the CollectionBase implementation may not be very efficient.

member.typeparam: The item type of the collection.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.PowerListBase`1.Range(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a view onto a sub-range of this list. Items are not copied; the returned IList<T> is simply a different view onto the same underlying items. Changes to this list are reflected in the view, and vice versa. Insertions and deletions in the view change the size of the view, but insertions and deletions in the underlying list do not.
member.remarks: This method can be used to apply an algorithm to a portion of a list. For example: Algorithms.ReverseInPlace(deque.Range(3, 6)) will reverse the 6 items beginning at index 3.
member.param: The starting index of the view.
The number of items in the view.
member.returns: A list that is a view onto the given sub-part of this list.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.Bag`1
member.summary: Bag<T> is a collection that contains items of type T. Unlike a Set, duplicate items (items that compare equal to each other) are allowed in an Bag.

remarks.p: The items are compared in one of two ways. If T implements IComparable<T> then the Equals method of that interface will be used to compare items, otherwise the Equals method from Object will be used. Alternatively, an instance of IComparer<T> can be passed to the constructor to use to compare items.
Bag is implemented as a hash table. Inserting, deleting, and looking up an an element all are done in approximately constant time, regardless of the number of items in the bag.

When multiple equal items are stored in the bag, they are stored as a representative item and a count. If equal items can be distinguished, this may be noticable. For example, if a case-insensitive comparer is used with a Bag<String>, and both "hello", and "HELLO" are added to the bag, then the bag will appear to contain two copies of "hello" (the representative item).
is similar, but uses comparison instead of hashing, maintain the items in sorted order, and stores distinct copies of items that compare equal.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Bag`1.System#ICloneable#Clone
member.summary: Makes a shallow clone of this bag; i.e., if items of the bag are reference types, then they are not cloned. If T is a value type, then each element is copied as if by simple assignment.
member.remarks: Cloning the bag takes time O(N), where N is the number of items in the bag.
member.returns: The cloned bag.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Bag`1.Clone
member.summary: Makes a shallow clone of this bag; i.e., if items of the bag are reference types, then they are not cloned. If T is a value type, then each element is copied as if by simple assignment.
member.remarks: Cloning the bag takes time O(N), where N is the number of unquie items in the bag.
member.returns: The cloned bag.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Bag`1.CloneContents
member.summary: Makes a deep clone of this bag. A new bag is created with a clone of each element of this bag, by calling ICloneable.Clone on each element. If T is a value type, then each element is copied as if by simple assignment.

remarks.para: If T is a reference type, it must implement ICloneable. Otherwise, an InvalidOperationException is thrown.
Cloning the bag takes time O(N log N), where N is the number of items in the bag.

member.returns: The cloned bag.
member.exception: T is a reference type that does not implement ICloneable.

member.summary: Returns the number of copies of in the bag.
member.remarks: NumberOfCopies() takes approximately constant time, no matter how many items are stored in the bag.
member.param: The item to search for in the bag.
member.returns: The number of items in the bag that compare equal to .

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Bag`1.GetRepresentativeItem(`0,`0@)
member.summary: Returns the representative item stored in the bag that is equal to the provided item. Also returns the number of copies of the item in the bag.
member.param: Item to find in the bag.
If one or more items equal to are present in the bag, returns the representative item. If no items equal to are stored in the bag, returns .
member.returns: The number of items equal to stored in the bag.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Bag`1.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an enumerator that enumerates all the items in the bag. If an item is present multiple times in the bag, the representative item is yielded by the enumerator multiple times. The order of enumeration is haphazard and may change.

remarks.p: Typically, this method is not called directly. Instead the "foreach" statement is used to enumerate the items, which uses this method implicitly.
If an item is added to or deleted from the bag while it is being enumerated, then the enumeration will end with an InvalidOperationException.
Enumeration all the items in the bag takes time O(N), where N is the number of items in the bag.

member.returns: An enumerator for enumerating all the items in the Bag.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Bag`1.Contains(`0)
member.summary: Determines if this bag contains an item equal to . The bag is not changed.
member.remarks: Searching the bag for an item takes time O(log N), where N is the number of items in the bag.
member.returns: True if the bag contains . False if the bag does not contain .

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Bag`1.DistinctItems
member.summary: Enumerates all the items in the bag, but enumerates equal items just once, even if they occur multiple times in the bag.
member.remarks: If the bag is changed while items are being enumerated, the enumeration will terminate with an InvalidOperationException.
member.returns: An IEnumerable<T> that enumerates the unique items.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Bag`1.Add(`0)
member.summary: Adds a new item to the bag. Since bags can contain duplicate items, the item is added even if the bag already contains an item equal to . In this case, the count of items for the representative item is increased by one, but the existing represetative item is unchanged.

remarks.para: Adding an item takes approximately constant time, regardless of the number of items in the bag.

member.param: The item to add to the bag.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Bag`1.AddRepresentative(`0)
member.summary: Adds a new item to the bag. Since bags can contain duplicate items, the item is added even if the bag already contains an item equal to . In this case (unlike Add), the new item becomes the representative item.

remarks.para: Adding an item takes approximately constant time, regardless of the number of items in the bag.

member.param: The item to add to the bag.

The new number of copies of the item.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1
member.summary: BigList<T> provides a list of items, in order, with indices of the items ranging from 0 to one less than the count of items in the collection. BigList<T> is optimized for efficient operations on large (>100 items) lists, especially for insertions, deletions, copies, and concatinations.

remarks.para: BigList<T> class is similar in functionality to the standard List<T> class. Both classes provide a collection that stores an set of items in order, with indices of the items ranging from 0 to one less than the count of items in the collection. Both classes provide the ability to add and remove items from any index, and the get or set the item at any index.

BigList<T> differs significantly from List<T> in the performance of various operations, especially when the lists become large (several hundred items or more). With List<T>, inserting or removing elements from anywhere in a large list except the end is very inefficient -- every item after the point of inserting or deletion has to be moved in the list. The BigList<T> class, however, allows for fast insertions and deletions anywhere in the list. Furthermore, BigList<T> allows copies of a list, sub-parts of a list, and concatinations of two lists to be very fast. When a copy is made of part or all of a BigList, two lists shared storage for the parts of the lists that are the same. Only when one of the lists is changed is additional memory allocated to store the distinct parts of the lists.

Of course, there is a small price to pay for this extra flexibility. Although still quite efficient, using an index to get or change one element of a BigList, while still reasonably efficient, is significantly slower than using a plain List. Because of this, if you want to process every element of a BigList, using a foreach loop is a lot more efficient than using a for loop and indexing the list.

In general, use a List when the only operations you are using are Add (to the end), foreach, or indexing, or you are very sure the list will always remain small (less than 100 items). For large (>100 items) lists that do insertions, removals, copies, concatinations, or sub-ranges, BigList will be more efficient than List. In almost all cases, BigList is more efficient and easier to use than LinkedList.

member.typeparam: The type of items to store in the BigList.

member.summary: Makes a deep clone of this BigList. A new BigList is created with a clone of each element of this set, by calling ICloneable.Clone on each element. If T is a value type, then this method is the same as Clone.

remarks.para: If T is a reference type, it must implement ICloneable. Otherwise, an InvalidOperationException is thrown.
If T is a reference type, cloning the list takes time approximate O(N), where N is the number of items in the list.

member.exception: T is a reference type that does not implement ICloneable.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Range(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a view onto a sub-range of this list. Items are not copied; the returned IList<T> is simply a different view onto the same underlying items. Changes to this list are reflected in the view, and vice versa. Insertions and deletions in the view change the size of the view, but insertions and deletions in the underlying list do not.
member.remarks:
If a copy of the sub-range is desired, use the method instead.
This method can be used to apply an algorithm to a portion of a list. For example: Algorithms.ReverseInPlace(list.Range(3, 6)) will reverse the 6 items beginning at index 3.
member.param: The starting index of the view.
The number of items in the view.
member.returns: A list that is a view onto the given sub-list.
member.exception: or is negative.

member.summary: Searches a sorted list for an item via binary search. The list must be sorted by the ordering defined by the passed Comparison<T> delegate; otherwise, incorrect results will be returned.
member.param: The comparison delegate used to sort the list.
member.returns: Returns the index of the first occurence of in the list. If the item does not occur in the list, the bitwise complement of the first item larger than in the list is returned. If no item is larger than , the bitwise complement of Count is returned.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Rebalance
member.summary: Rebalance the current tree. Once rebalanced, the depth of the current tree is no more than two levels from fully balanced, where fully balanced is defined as having Fibonacci(N+2) or more items in a tree of depth N.
member.remarks: The rebalancing algorithm is from "Ropes: an Alternative to Strings", by Boehm, Atkinson, and Plass, in SOFTWARE--PRACTICE AND EXPERIENCE, VOL. 25(12), 13151330 (DECEMBER 1995).

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.StopEnumerations
member.summary: Must be called whenever there is a structural change in the tree. Causes changeStamp to be changed, which causes any in-progress enumerations to throw exceptions.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.CheckEnumerationStamp(System.Int32)
member.summary: Checks the given stamp against the current change stamp. If different, the collection has changed during enumeration and an InvalidOperationException must be thrown
member.param: changeStamp at the start of the enumeration.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.GetEnumerator(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Enumerates a range of the items in the list, in order. The item at is enumerated first, then the next item at index 1, and so on. At most items are enumerated.
member.remarks: Enumerating all of the items in the list take time O(N), where N is the number of items being enumerated. Using GetEnumerator() or foreach is much more efficient than accessing all items by index.
member.param: Max number of items to enumerate.
member.returns: An IEnumerator<T> that enumerates all the items in the given range.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.NodeFromEnumerable(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Given an IEnumerable<T>, create a new Node with all of the items in the enumerable. Returns null if the enumerable has no items.
member.returns: Returns a Node, not shared or with any shared children, with the items from the collection. If the collection was empty, null is returned.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.LeafFromEnumerator(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerator{`0})
member.summary: Consumes up to MAXLEAF items from an Enumerator and places them in a leaf node. If the enumerator is at the end, null is returned.
member.param: The enumerator to take items from.
member.returns: A LeafNode with items taken from the enumerator.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.NCopiesOfNode(System.Int32,DmFramework.Collections.BigList{`0}.Node)
member.summary: Create a node that has N copies of the given node.
member.param: Number of copies. Must be non-negative.
member.returns: null if node is null or copies is 0. Otherwise, a node consisting of copies of node.
member.exception: copies is negative.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.CheckBalance
member.summary: Check the balance of the current tree and rebalance it if it is more than BALANCEFACTOR levels away from fully balanced. Note that rebalancing a tree may leave it two levels away from fully balanced.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.AddNodeToRebalanceArray(DmFramework.Collections.BigList{`0}.Node[],DmFramework.Collections.BigList{`0}.Node,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Part of the rebalancing algorithm. Adds a node to the rebalance array. If it is already balanced, add it directly, otherwise add its children.
member.param: If true, mark the node as shared before adding, because one of its parents was shared.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.AddBalancedNodeToRebalanceArray(DmFramework.Collections.BigList{`0}.Node[],DmFramework.Collections.BigList{`0}.Node)
member.summary: Part of the rebalancing algorithm. Adds a balanced node to the rebalance array.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of items stored in the BigList. The indices of the items range from 0 to Count-1.
member.remarks: Getting the number of items in the BigList takes constant time.
member.value: The number of items in the BigList.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets or sets an item in the list, by index.

remarks.para: Gettingor setting an item takes time O(log N), where N is the number of items in the list.
To process each of the items in the list, using GetEnumerator() or a foreach loop is more efficient that accessing each of the elements by index.

member.param: The index of the item to get or set. The first item in the list has index 0, the last item has index Count-1.
member.returns: The value of the item at the given index.
member.exception: is less than zero or greater than or equal to Count.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node
member.summary: The base class for the two kinds of nodes in the tree: Concat nodes and Leaf nodes.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node.MarkShared
member.summary: Marks this node as shared by setting the shared variable.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node.GetAt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the items at the given index in this node.
member.returns: Item at that index.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node.Subrange(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a node that has a sub-range of items from this node. The sub-range may not be empty, but may extend outside the node. In other words, first might be less than zero or last might be greater than count. But, last can't be less than zero and first can't be greater than count. Also, last must be greater than or equal to last.
member.param: Inclusive first element, relative to this node.
Inclusize last element, relative to this node.
member.returns: Node with the given sub-range.

New item to place at the given index.
member.returns: A new node with the given item changed.

member.param: Index, relative to this node, to change.
New item to place at the given index.
member.returns: A node with the give item changed. If it can be done in place then "this" is returned.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node.Append(DmFramework.Collections.BigList{`0}.Node,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Append a node after this node. Never changes this node, but returns a new node with the given appending done.
member.param: If true, the given node is not used in any current list, so it may be change, overwritten, or destroyed if convenient. If false, the given node is in use. It should be marked as shared if is is used within the return value.
member.returns: A new node with the give node appended to this node.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node.AppendInPlace(DmFramework.Collections.BigList{`0}.Node,System.Boolean)

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node.AppendInPlace(`0)
member.summary: Append a item after this node. May change this node, or return a new node. Equivalent to AppendInPlace(new LeafNode(item), true), but may be more efficient because a new LeafNode might not be allocated.
member.returns: A node with the given item appended to this node. May be a new node or the current node.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node.RemoveRange(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Remove a range of items from this node. Never changes this node, but returns a new node with the removing done. The sub-range may not be empty, but may extend outside the node. In other words, first might be less than zero or last might be greater than count. But, last can't be less than zero and first can't be greater than count. Also, last must be greater than or equal to last.
member.param: Inclusive index of first item in sub-range, relative to this node.
Inclusize index of last item in sub-range, relative to this node.
member.returns: A new node with the sub-range removed.

In other words, first might be less than zero or last might be greater than count. But, last can't be less than zero and first can't be greater than count. Also, last must be greater than or equal to last.
member.param: Inclusive index of first item in sub-range, relative to this node.
Inclusize index of last item in sub-range, relative to this node.
member.returns: A node with the sub-range removed. If done in-place, returns "this".

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node.IsBalanced
member.summary: Determine if this node is balanced. A node is balanced if the number of items is greater than Fibonacci(Depth+2). Balanced nodes are never rebalanced unless they go out of balance again.
member.returns: True if the node is balanced by this definition.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node.IsAlmostBalanced
member.summary: Determine if this node is almost balanced. A node is almost balanced if t its depth is at most one greater than a fully balanced node with the same count.
member.returns: True if the node is almost balanced by this definition.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node.Count

member.summary: Is this node shared by more that one list (or within a single) lists. If true, indicates that this node, and any nodes below it, may never be modified. Never becomes false after being set to true.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.Node.Depth
member.summary: Gets the depth of this node. A leaf node has depth 0, a concat node with two leaf children has depth 1, etc.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.LeafNode
member.summary: The LeafNode class is the type of node that lives at the leaf of a tree and holds the actual items stored in the list. Each leaf holds at least 1, and at most MAXLEAF items in the items array. The number of items stored is found in "count", which may be less than "items.Length".

member.name: F:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.LeafNode.items
member.summary: Array that stores the items in the nodes. Always has a least "count" elements, but may have more as padding.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.ConcatNode.NewNode(DmFramework.Collections.BigList{`0}.Node,DmFramework.Collections.BigList{`0}.Node)
member.summary: Create a new node with the given children. Mark unchanged children as shared. There are four possible cases: 1. If one of the new children is null, the other new child is returned. 2. If neither child has changed, then this is marked as shared as returned. 3. If one child has changed, the other child is marked shared an a new node is returned. 4. If both children have changed, a new node is returned.
member.returns: New node with the given children. Returns null if and only if both new children are null.

member.returns: Node with the given children. Usually, but not always, this. Returns null if and only if both new children are null.

Also, last must be greater than or equal to last.
member.param: Inclusive index of first item in sub-range, relative to this node.
Inclusize index of last item in sub-range, relative to this node.

Also, last must be greater than or equal to last.
member.param: Inclusive first element, relative to this node.
Inclusize last element, relative to this node.
member.returns: Node with the given sub-range.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.ConcatNode.Depth
member.summary: The depth of this node -- the maximum length path to a leaf. If this node has two children that are leaves, the depth in 1.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.BigList`1.BigListRange
member.summary: The class that is used to implement IList<T> to view a sub-range of a BigList. The object stores a wrapped list, and a start/count indicating a sub-range of the list. Insertion/deletions through the sub-range view cause the count to change also; insertions and deletions directly on the wrapped list do not.
member.remarks: This is different from Algorithms.Range in a very few respects: it is specialized to only wrap BigList, and it is a lot more efficient in enumeration.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1

summary.para: The Deque class implements a type of list known as a Double Ended Queue. A Deque is quite similar to a List, in that items have indices (starting at 0), and the item at any index can be efficiently retrieved. The difference between a List and a Deque lies in the efficiency of inserting elements at the beginning. In a List, items can be efficiently added to the end, but inserting an item at the beginning of the List is slow, taking time proportional to the size of the List. In a Deque, items can be added to the beginning or end equally efficiently, regardless of the number of items in the Deque. As a trade-off for this increased flexibility, Deque is somewhat slower than List (but still constant time) when being indexed to get or retrieve elements.

remarks.para: The Deque class can also be used as a more flexible alternative to the Queue and Stack classes. Deque is as efficient as Queue and Stack for adding or removing items, but is more flexible: it allows access to all items in the queue, and allows adding or removing from either end.
Deque is implemented as a ring buffer, which is grown as necessary. The size of the buffer is doubled whenever the existing capacity is too small to hold all the elements.

member.typeparam: The type of items stored in the Deque.

member.summary: Create a new Deque that is initially empty.

member.summary: Create a new Deque initialized with the items from the passed collection, in order.
member.param: A collection of items to initialize the Deque with.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.CopyTo(`0[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies all the items in the Deque into an array.
member.param: Starting index in to copy to.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.TrimToSize
member.summary: Trims the amount of memory used by the Deque by changing the Capacity to be equal to Count. If no more items will be added to the Deque, calling TrimToSize will reduce the amount of memory used by the Deque.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.Clear
member.summary: Removes all items from the Deque.
member.remarks: Clearing the Deque takes a small constant amount of time, regardless of how many items are currently in the Deque.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Enumerates all of the items in the list, in order. The item at index 0 is enumerated first, then the item at index 1, and so on. If the items are added to or removed from the Deque during enumeration, the enumeration ends with an InvalidOperationException.
member.returns: An IEnumerator<T> that enumerates all the items in the list.
member.exception: The Deque has an item added or deleted during the enumeration.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.Insert(System.Int32,`0)
member.summary: Inserts a new item at the given index in the Deque. All items at indexes equal to or greater than move up one index in the Deque.
member.remarks: The amount of time to insert an item in the Deque is proportional to the distance of index from the closest end of the Deque: O(Min(, Count - )). Thus, inserting an item at the front or end of the Deque is always fast; the middle of of the Deque is the slowest place to insert.
member.param: The index in the Deque to insert the item at. After the insertion, the inserted item is located at this index. The front item in the Deque has index 0.
The item to insert at the given index.
member.exception: is less than zero or greater than Count.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.InsertRange(System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Inserts a collection of items at the given index in the Deque. All items at indexes equal to or greater than increase their indices in the Deque by the number of items inserted.
member.remarks: The amount of time to insert a collection in the Deque is proportional to the distance of index from the closest end of the Deque, plus the number of items inserted (M): O(M + Min(, Count - )).
member.param: The index in the Deque to insert the collection at. After the insertion, the first item of the inserted collection is located at this index. The front item in the Deque has index 0.
The collection of items to insert at the given index.
member.exception: is less than zero or greater than Count.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.RemoveAt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the item at the given index in the Deque. All items at indexes greater than move down one index in the Deque.
member.remarks: The amount of time to delete an item in the Deque is proportional to the distance of index from the closest end of the Deque: O(Min(, Count - 1 - )). Thus, deleting an item at the front or end of the Deque is always fast; the middle of of the Deque is the slowest place to delete.
member.param: The index in the list to remove the item at. The first item in the list has index 0.
member.exception: is less than zero or greater than or equal to Count.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.RemoveRange(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes a range of items at the given index in the Deque. All items at indexes greater than move down indices in the Deque.
member.remarks: The amount of time to delete items in the Deque is proportional to the distance to the closest end of the Deque: O(Min(, Count - - )).
member.param: The index in the list to remove the range at. The first item in the list has index 0.
The number of items to remove.
member.exception: is less than zero or greater than or equal to Count, or is less than zero or too large.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.AddToFront(`0)
member.summary: Adds an item to the front of the Deque. The indices of all existing items in the Deque are increased by 1. This method is equivalent to Insert(0, item) but is a little more efficient.
member.remarks: Adding an item to the front of the Deque takes a small constant amount of time, regardless of how many items are in the Deque.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.AddManyToFront(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Adds a collection of items to the front of the Deque. The indices of all existing items in the Deque are increased by the number of items inserted. The first item in the added collection becomes the first item in the Deque.
member.remarks: This method takes time O(M), where M is the number of items in the .
member.param: The collection of items to add.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.AddToBack(`0)
member.summary: Adds an item to the back of the Deque. The indices of all existing items in the Deque are unchanged. This method is equivalent to Insert(Count, item) but is a little more efficient.
member.remarks: Adding an item to the back of the Deque takes a small constant amount of time, regardless of how many items are in the Deque.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.Add(`0)
member.summary: Adds an item to the back of the Deque. The indices of all existing items in the Deque are unchanged. This method is equivalent to AddToBack(item).
member.remarks: Adding an item to the back of the Deque takes a small constant amount of time, regardless of how many items are in the Deque.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.AddManyToBack(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0})
member.summary: Adds a collection of items to the back of the Deque. The indices of all existing items in the Deque are unchanged. The last item in the added collection becomes the last item in the Deque.
member.remarks: This method takes time O(M), where M is the number of items in the .
member.param: The collection of item to add.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.RemoveFromFront
member.summary: Removes an item from the front of the Deque. The indices of all existing items in the Deque are decreased by 1. This method is equivalent to RemoveAt(0) but is a little more efficient.
member.remarks: Removing an item from the front of the Deque takes a small constant amount of time, regardless of how many items are in the Deque.
member.returns: The item that was removed.
member.exception: The Deque is empty.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.RemoveFromBack
member.summary: Removes an item from the back of the Deque. The indices of all existing items in the Deque are unchanged. This method is equivalent to RemoveAt(Count-1) but is a little more efficient.
member.remarks: Removing an item from the back of the Deque takes a small constant amount of time, regardless of how many items are in the Deque.
member.exception: The Deque is empty.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.GetAtFront
member.summary: Retreives the item currently at the front of the Deque. The Deque is unchanged. This method is equivalent to deque[0] (except that a different exception is thrown).
member.remarks: Retreiving the item at the front of the Deque takes a small constant amount of time, regardless of how many items are in the Deque.
member.returns: The item at the front of the Deque.
member.exception: The Deque is empty.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.GetAtBack
member.summary: Retreives the item currently at the back of the Deque. The Deque is unchanged. This method is equivalent to deque[deque.Count - 1] (except that a different exception is thrown).
member.remarks: Retreiving the item at the back of the Deque takes a small constant amount of time, regardless of how many items are in the Deque.
member.returns: The item at the back of the Deque.
member.exception: The Deque is empty.

member.summary: Creates a new Deque that is a copy of this one.
member.remarks: Copying a Deque takes O(N) time, where N is the number of items in this Deque..

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.System#ICloneable#Clone
member.summary: Creates a new Deque that is a copy of this one.
member.remarks: Copying a Deque takes O(N) time, where N is the number of items in this Deque..
member.returns: A copy of the current deque.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.CloneContents
member.summary: Makes a deep clone of this Deque. A new Deque is created with a clone of each element of this set, by calling ICloneable.Clone on each element. If T is a value type, then each element is copied as if by simple assignment.

remarks.para: If T is a reference type, it must implement ICloneable. Otherwise, an InvalidOperationException is thrown.
Cloning the Deque takes time O(N), where N is the number of items in the Deque.

member.returns: The cloned Deque.
member.exception: T is a reference type that does not implement ICloneable.

member.summary: Must be called whenever there is a structural change in the tree. Causes changeStamp to be changed, which causes any in-progress enumerations to throw exceptions.

member.summary: Checks the given stamp against the current change stamp. If different, the collection has changed during enumeration and an InvalidOperationException must be thrown

member.summary: Increase the amount of buffer space. When calling this method, the Deque must not be empty. If start and end are equal, that indicates a completely full Deque.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of items currently stored in the Deque. The last item in the Deque has index Count-1.
member.remarks: Getting the count of items in the Deque takes a small constant amount of time.
member.value: The number of items stored in this Deque.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.Capacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the capacity of the Deque. The Capacity is the number of items that this Deque can hold without expanding its internal buffer. Since Deque will automatically expand its buffer when necessary, in almost all cases it is unnecessary to worry about the capacity. However, if it is known that a Deque will contain exactly 1000 items eventually, it can slightly improve efficiency to set the capacity to 1000 up front, so that the Deque does not have to expand automatically.
member.value: The number of items that this Deque can hold without expanding its internal buffer.
member.exception: The capacity is being set to less than Count, or to too large a value.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.Deque`1.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets or sets an item at a particular index in the Deque.
member.remarks: Getting or setting the item at a particular index takes a small constant amount of time, no matter what index is used.
member.param: The index of the item to retrieve or change. The front item has index 0, and the back item has index Count-1.
member.returns: The value at the indicated index.
member.exception: The index is less than zero or greater than or equal to Count.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.ReadOnlyCollectionBase`1
member.summary: ReadOnlyCollectionBase is a base class that can be used to more easily implement the generic ICollection<T> and non-generic ICollection interfaces for a read-only collection: a collection that does not allow adding or removing elements.

remarks.para: To use ReadOnlyCollectionBase as a base class, the derived class must override the Count and GetEnumerator methods.
ICollection<T>.Contains need not be implemented by the derived class, but it should be strongly considered, because the ReadOnlyCollectionBase implementation may not be very efficient.

member.typeparam: The item type of the collection.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.ReadOnlyCollectionBase`1.MethodModifiesCollection
member.summary: Throws an NotSupportedException stating that this collection cannot be modified.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1
member.summary: The base implementation for various collections classes that use hash tables as part of their implementation. This class should not (and can not) be used directly by end users; it's only for internal use by the collections package. The Hash does not handle duplicate values.
member.remarks: The Hash manages items of type T, and uses a IComparer<ItemTYpe> that hashes compares items to hash items into the table.

member.summary: Constructor. Create a new hash table.
member.param: The comparer to use to compare items.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.GetEnumerationStamp
member.summary: Gets the current enumeration stamp. Call CheckEnumerationStamp later with this value to throw an exception if the hash table is changed.
member.returns: The current enumeration stamp.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.StopEnumerations
member.summary: Must be called whenever there is a structural change in the tree. Causes changeStamp to be changed, which causes any in-progress enumerations to throw exceptions.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.CheckEnumerationStamp(System.Int32)
member.summary: Checks the given stamp against the current change stamp. If different, the collection has changed during enumeration and an InvalidOperationException must be thrown
member.param: changeStamp at the start of the enumeration.

member.summary: Insert a new item into the hash table. If a duplicate item exists, can replace or do nothing.
member.param: If true, duplicate items are replaced. If false, nothing is done if a duplicate already exists.
If a duplicate was found, returns it (whether replaced or not).
member.returns: True if no duplicate existed, false if a duplicate was found.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.Delete(`0,`0@)
member.summary: Deletes an item from the hash table.
member.param: Item to search for and delete.
If true returned, the actual item stored in the hash table (must be equal to , but may not be identical.
member.returns: True if item was found and deleted, false if item wasn't found.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.Find(`0,System.Boolean,`0@)
member.summary: Find an item in the hash table. If found, optionally replace it with the finding item.
member.param: If true, replaces the equal item in the hash table with .
Returns the equal item found in the table, if true was returned.
member.returns: True if the item was found, false otherwise.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Enumerate all of the items in the hash table. The items are enumerated in a haphazard, unpredictable order.
member.returns: An IEnumerator<T> that enumerates the items in the hash table.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.System#Collections#IEnumerable#GetEnumerator
member.summary: Enumerate all of the items in the hash table. The items are enumerated in a haphazard, unpredictable order.
member.returns: An IEnumerator that enumerates the items in the hash table.

member.summary: Creates a clone of this hash table.
member.param: If non-null, this function is applied to each item when cloning. It must be the case that this function does not modify the hash code or equality function.
member.returns: A shallow clone that contains the same items.

member.summary: Gets the full hash code for an item.
member.param: Item to get hash code for.
member.returns: The full hash code. It is never zero.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.GetHashValuesFromFullHash(System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Get the initial bucket number and skip amount from the full hash value.
member.param: Returns the initial bucket. Always in the range 0..(totalSlots - 1).
Returns the skip values. Always odd in the range 0..(totalSlots - 1).

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.GetHashValues(`0,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Gets the full hash value, initial bucket number, and skip amount for an item.
member.param: Item to get hash value of.
Returns the initial bucket. Always in the range 0..(totalSlots - 1).
Returns the skip values. Always odd in the range 0..(totalSlots - 1).
member.returns: The full hash value. This is never zero.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.EnsureEnoughSlots(System.Int32)
member.summary: Make sure there are enough slots in the hash table that items can be inserted into the table.
member.param: Number of additional items we are inserting.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.ShrinkIfNeeded
member.summary: Check if the number of items in the table is small enough that we should shrink the table again.

member.summary: Given the size of a hash table, compute the "secondary shift" value -- the shift that is used to determine the skip amount for collision resolution.
member.param: The new size of the table.
member.returns: The secondary skip amount.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.ResizeTable(System.Int32)
member.summary: Resize the hash table to the given new size, moving all items into the new hash table.
member.param: The new size of the hash table. Must be a power of two.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.System#Runtime#Serialization#ISerializable#GetObjectData(System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo,System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext)
member.summary: Serialize the hash table. Called from the serialization infrastructure.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.#ctor(System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo,System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext)
member.summary: Called on deserialization. We cannot deserialize now, because hash codes might not be correct now. We do real deserialization in the OnDeserialization call.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.System#Runtime#Serialization#IDeserializationCallback#OnDeserialization(System.Object)
member.summary: Deserialize the hash table. Called from the serialization infrastructure when the object graph has finished deserializing.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.ElementCount
member.summary: Get the number of items in the hash table.
member.value: The number of items stored in the hash table.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.SlotCount
member.summary: Get the number of slots in the hash table. Exposed internally for testing purposes.
member.value: The number of slots in the hash table.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.LoadFactor
member.summary: Get or change the load factor. Changing the load factor may cause the size of the table to grow or shrink accordingly.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.Slot
member.summary: The structure that has each slot in the hash table. Each slot has three parts: 1. The collision bit. Indicates whether some item visited this slot but had to keep looking because the slot was full. 2. 31-bit full hash value of the item. If zero, the slot is empty. 3. The item itself.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.Slot.Clear
member.summary: Clear this slot, leaving the collision bit alone.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.Slot.HashValue
member.summary: The full hash value associated with the value in this slot, or zero if the slot is empty.

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.Slot.Empty
member.summary: Is this slot empty?

member.name: P:DmFramework.Collections.Hash`1.Slot.Collision
member.summary: The "Collision" bit indicates that some value hit this slot and collided, so had to try another slot.

members.member:
Dictionary implementing the hot swap model. Is a completely thread safe collection with lock-less read and very slow write operations.
[DebuggerStepThrough]

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.MultiDictionary`2

summary.para: The MultiDictionary class that associates values with a key. Unlike an Dictionary, each key can have multiple values associated with it. When indexing an MultiDictionary, instead of a single value associated with a key, you retrieve an enumeration of values.
When constructed, you can chose to allow the same value to be associated with a key multiple times, or only one time.

member.typeparam: The type of the keys.
The of values associated with the keys.

member.name: T:DmFramework.Collections.MultiDictionaryBase`2
member.summary: MultiDictionaryBase is a base class that can be used to more easily implement a class that associates multiple values to a single key. The class implements the generic IDictionary<TKey, ICollection<TValue>> interface.

remarks.para: To use MultiDictionaryBase as a base class, the derived class must override Count, Clear, Add, Remove(TKey), Remove(TKey,TValue), Contains(TKey,TValue), EnumerateKeys, and TryEnumerateValuesForKey.
It may wish consider overriding CountValues, CountAllValues, ContainsKey, and EqualValues, but these are not required.

member.typeparam: The key type of the dictionary.
The value type of the dictionary.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.MultiDictionaryBase`2.Clear
member.summary: Clears the dictionary. This method must be overridden in the derived class.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.MultiDictionaryBase`2.EnumerateKeys
member.summary: Enumerate all the keys in the dictionary. This method must be overridden by a derived class.
member.returns: An IEnumerator<TKey> that enumerates all of the keys in the collection that have at least one value associated with them.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.MultiDictionaryBase`2.TryEnumerateValuesForKey(`0,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerator{`1}@)
member.summary: Enumerate all of the values associated with a given key. This method must be overridden by the derived class. If the key exists and has values associated with it, an enumerator for those values is returned throught . If the key does not exist, false is returned.
member.param: The key to get values for.
If true is returned, this parameter receives an enumerators that enumerates the values associated with that key.
member.returns: True if the key exists and has values associated with it. False otherwise.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.MultiDictionaryBase`2.Add(System.Collections.Generic.KeyValuePair{`0,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{`1}})
member.summary: Adds a key-value pair to the collection. The value part of the pair must be a collection of values to associate with the key. If values are already associated with the given key, the new values are added to the ones associated with that key.
member.param: A KeyValuePair contains the Key and Value collection to add.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.MultiDictionaryBase`2.System#Collections#Generic#IDictionary{TKey@System#Collections#Generic#ICollection{TValue}}#Add(`0,System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{`1})
member.summary: Implements IDictionary<TKey, IEnumerable<TValue>>.Add. If the key is already present, and ArgumentException is thrown. Otherwise, a new key is added, and new values are associated with that key.
member.param: Values to associate with that key.
member.exception: The key is already present in the dictionary.

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.MultiDictionaryBase`2.AddMany(`0,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`1})

summary.para: Adds new values to be associated with a key. If duplicate values are permitted, this method always adds new key-value pairs to the dictionary.
If duplicate values are not permitted, and already has a value equal to one of associated with it, then that value is replaced, and the number of values associate with is unchanged.

member.param: A collection of values to associate with .

member.name: M:DmFramework.Collections.MultiDictionaryBase`2.Add(`0,`1)
member.summary: Adds a new key-value pair to the dictionary. This method must be overridden in the derived class.
member.param: Value to associated with the key.
member.exception: key is already present in the dictionary

member.summary: Removes a key from the dictionary. This method must be overridden in the derived class.

member.returns: True if the key was found, false otherwise.

member.summary: Removes a key-value pair from the dictionary. This method must be overridden in the derived class.

Associated value to remove from the dictionary.
member.returns: True if the key-value pair was found, false otherwise.

member.summary: Remove all of the keys (and any associated values) in a collection of keys. If a key is not present in the dictionary, nothing happens.

member.summary: Determines if this dictionary contains a key equal to . If so, all the values associated with that key are returned through the values parameter. This method must be overridden by the derived class.
